comments.commentBody: Finally he is coming to the table to cut the pay of these bloated self-serving government workers.  Its time for these civil servants to  realize that's what they are: civil servants. That any of these people get a bonus is criminal!

"When they dragged the overpaid congresspersons and senators off in Ford F150's to the gallows, I said nothing because I was not a congressperson or senator, nor did I know any. When they bound the lobbyists of K Street and threw them into the Potomac, I said nothing because I did not know any of them or like the idea of them much, either. When they burned and looted the gated communities, I said nothing because I knew no one who lived in one and could never afford to, anyhow. When they locked the doors of the public housing projects and set them on fire, I said nothing because I was never certain that the funds spent on them did any good and knew no one who lived in them. When they burned the libraries and universities, I said nothing because I'd learned most of what I know via the internet for years and knew no librarians, teachers or students. When they looted the malls and box stores and lynched the police and National Guard reservists, I said nothing because I think zombie movies and first-person shooter military video games are really neat. Hey, what happened to the electricity and water and who are those yelling people coming down my street?" Fake enemies offered in real distress. Follow money to unelected instigators. Consider reflection in mirror closely.

Every responsible employer has had to look at its payroll expenses. Government is no different.

Democrats will never get anywhere if they cannot even freeze spending.

I am so nervous because this is my first post here.  Actually, I’m not.  I could care less.  This puzzle is ODD.  I felt like I was playing Pick 4 boxed 6 ways.   Then it had all these references to being a drunk and that triggered my DTs.  But no I had to go until I saw that it was IN USE. Next came the insults.  I was a JAG (Judge Advocate General) in the Air Force and didn’t think of that as bingeing.  AROD is getting $275 mil?  Somebody had to be drinking to give any ball player that much.  No wonder the Yankees think some players are richer than the owners.  Then there was that GATO that fell off el tejado.  Tomorrow it will be in a coma and by Thursday it will be muerto.  I don’t JEST and don’t call me Surely.  So long, Leslie....
good puzzle; great cartoon. thanks for the chuckles!

An old friend of mine used to define a person with class as someone who could hear Rossini's William Tell Overture and not immediately think of the Lone Ranger. Now I'm afraid that recognizing it as the TLR theme song might be a sign of age...

I'm just back from an out-of-town, computer-free trip and was having a wonderfully relaxing evening catching up on the week's puzzles when I ran into yesterday's news about Patrick and Jim. I hope it wasn't something we said (or failed to say)!! I'm sorry to be late in joining the masses by offering a very fond farewell. On more than one occasion I have pondered the awesome responsibility you hold of providing witty, insightful analysis day after day after day and wondered how you managed. I'm sorry we weren't able to perfect the MHP recipe in time to provide some inspiration and/or stress relief. ANYHOO, thanks very much for all that you've shared with us and especially for the many times that you have saved me from asking silly questions by oh-so-gently providing the key information that led to the forehead slap. I look forward to your continued comments on the blog whenever you feel like it -- and only when you feel like it! I also look forward to seeing more of Deb Amlen's contributions and have no doubt that she will be a wonderful addition to the community.

@Suzy M, Chaos130, Dr. W -- At the risk of seeming like a TOPER (new word for me today...so had to use it) I've also been thinking about recipe possibilities. How about Midori, Herradura, and [something starting with P]. All I'm coming up with at the moment is pomegranate juice, which is probably too trendy for MHP's tastes; I'm also not sure about the resulting color. Pimm's? Perrier?
You guys have exemplified smart and civil discourse about the crosswords we love. All the best!

Wrongheaded pandering to the overpaid fed worker myth or clever tactical move. I hope the latter, but find that it's more likely the former. Now the good congress people and Senators can vote themselves a pay cut and loss of insurance. They are definitely overpaid federal workers who do little for their wages.

I'm unemployed. I checked out the compensation for the CEO of the major corporation I was laid off from in 2009. His total compensation is 2 million plus.

So I'm supposed to cheer that middle class people like me get a pay freeze? No, I won't do it. It's further evidence that the middle class is under assault.

The broad sacrifice the President speaks of must also include those groups of people who amassed a great deal of wealth by causing the "recession" in the first place.

Those fighting to keep the Bush tax cuts for the top income earners in society should be publicly shamed for doing so. Elected officials who support cutting taxes for these wealthiest among us must receive censure from the voting public.

Don't go soft on this issue Mr President. If it is the responsibility of the public to sacrifice for the good of the country, then the wealthy bare the greatest share of this responsibility. They profited the most during the bubble. They were harmed the least. And thus they must contribute the most.

If that is not acceptable, then as Chief Executive you have a responsibility to launch criminal investigations against specific players and seize their assets to restore what has been wrongfully stolen from the citizenry that depended on them.
Could the celebration be changed into celebration of mutual reconciliation and commitment to betterment of all the people?  Remember "One Nation...Indivisible with Justice for All"

This is all fine and dandy. If any one needs me, I'll be celebrating Redcoat Day and the joyous period of history of when we (well some of us) tried to stick it to those uppity rebels who tried so hard to make the US independent from our fair mother Britannia. We'll praise King George III and our long neglected and long abandoned traditions of inherited nobility and inhibited economic development.

Rick Perry of Texas keeps threatening to secede. I wish the whole south would go along with them.
We would all be better off.
And it would help with our nations deficit budget too.

I now live in the deep south after living in Maryland, which is south of the Mason Dixon Line.  I am sure it will be a big deal here for the promotion of the secession. Meanwhile, the schools are struggling financially and educationally but somehow the state of Alabama can justify paying a college football coach $4 million dollars a year.
We sometimes support the right of states (e.g. Tibet, Estonia, Kosovo) to secede from rival nations (e.g. China, Soviet Union, Yugoslavia).  Sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't.
Let them go, and if they don't want to anymore, make them! We will be better off if the South secedes.
Disgraceful, pure and simple.

Great, let's tackle one percent of this problem head on.  Who is BO trying to please?  Who is he afraid of?  Pretty hard to tell what's going on with this guy.  Why not come out boldly against extending tax cuts for billionaires because of the damage they do to the deficit?  Why not make corporations pay income taxes?  Change you can believe in becomes brother, can you spare a dime?
My company didn't do so well last year.  So we didn't get raises.  That's the real world.  I hope that Federal workers will realize this.  No raises beats no job.

Last week I had an interesting conversation with a gentleman from another country about United States history, mostly about the US Civil War and its aftermath. I was born in county in the North that claims to have had the most soldiers per capita in the "Conflict Between the States" and have read many histories, attended lectures, visited battlefields, and participated in many discussions about it over the last 40 years. One can debate the root causes or the sanitation of histories until the end of time and it will not erase the suffering of countless souls: civilians, soldiers, and veterans.

I heartily agree with the some of the comments about moving on - there were many good people on both sides that did great things, but not to learn from the mistakes of hate and greed is illogical. I felt the same sick feeling about the waste of lives at Gettysburg, Antietam, and at the mass Confederate grave site at Warrenton, VA. As a son of a soldier who had seen 3 wars in his lifetime, I have learned to look upon war as an unnecessary evil that the world could live without. Mark Twain in his wisdom and humanity wrote "The War Prayer" in hopes of taking romance out of war and exposing it as the vile, evil thing that it really is in this life.

@#11: They fought for their right to own other human beings. The American Dream in the South, as has been written elsewhere, was to be seen coming down the road with a black slave following you. Even the Southerners who didn't own slaves willing fought so they could have the right to pursue that ugly, evil dream. And that's not even talking about the horrors of slave life, which included constant deprivation, routine beatings, sexual violence and abuse and the ever-present threat of seeing your loved ones sold down the river. Those are the "states' rights" the Confederacy upheld. Give me human rights instead.

Anyone who tells you the Civil War was not started by slavery is either deeply misinformed or openly lying. A small group of planters who owned most of the wealth in their region had all their capital tied up in a brutal, vicious system that made industrialization -- and its leveling benefits -- almost impossible. There was no reason for them to betray their country unless they were desperate to hold onto the fetters around the black man's neck. All the issues that led to secession -- states' rights, tariffs, nullification -- stemmed from the need of a population of 5 million whites to control 4 million blacks. You can't justify it, you can't rationalize it, you can't pretend slavery was just a side issue. The leaders of the Confederacy were, in the main, thugs, traitors and rapists.

The revisionists (and now teapartiers) have been saying for awhile that the Civil War wasn't really about slavery, but was all about states' rights. While states' rights has been an issue since the federalists and anti-federalists, I'm pretty sure there would not have been a Civil War without the horrific institution of slavery as the primary offense.

And don't forget the South's KKK, lynchings, Jim Crow and their other heavily racist policies they were forced to give up -- is that all about states' rights too?

Celebrating secession is tantamount to celebrating slavery.
Does this include both houses
Read "Disunion" in the NYT if you want to know what actual Southerners were saying about why they wanted to secede.

Quote from the Associated Press :
"It would not affect members of Congress or their staffs, defense contractors, postal workers or federal court judges and workers."

First of all, why are members of Congress and their staffs exempted from the freeze ? They should be first in line for the freeze! You lead by example !
Second, why are defense contractors, postal workers, and federal court workers exempted? On what basis ? There is no good reason for that.

And last, but not least, why did the NY Times article leave out this important part of the news on the federal pay freeze ???
